text: Hi-Fi Rush é um jogo maravilhoso que saiu da equipe do pai do survival horror, o que deixa muita gente confusa, afinal, um hack n' slash rítmico vindo da equipe do pai do survival horror? Pois é. Hi-Fi Rush é um jogo para mostrar que a Tango GameWorks não depende apenas de The Evil Within ou Ghostwire, ela pode desenvolver jogos de diferentes gêneros,  com diferentes estilos gráficos, e ainda assim ele será incrível. A direção artística do jogo é fenomenal, o estilo cartunesco com cenários em 3D e cell shadding funcionam como um finíssimo vinho, e vão permitir ao jogo que envelheça muito bem. A mecânica de gameplay é extremamente divertida e fluida, se comportando de forma semelhante a outros hack n slash, mas inovando em como manter pontuações, afinal, estamos falando de um jogo rítmico. Para um bom jogo rítmico funcionar, precisamos de uma excelente trilha sonora, e é exatamente o que temos em Hi-Fi Rush, o sample base é maravilhoso, e conforme vamos acertando os golpes a intensidade da trilha vai aumentando, até mesmo quando quebramos caixotes em busca de peças escutamos a plateia gritando pelo nosso protagonista "CHAI, CHAI, CHAI!". Este jogo veio para surpreender todos os jogadores e mostrar que jogos não precisam ter medo de serem apenas jogos. Realismo gráfico, histórias dramáticas, pra que? Nossa vida já é cheia de tristezas, está na hora de voltarmos a nos divertir, e se divertir com Hi-Fi Rush!

This game is an absolute blast and within one day has easily become one of my favorite games of all time. Robbie Daymond knocks is out of the park as Chai and the rest of the voice cast is a pure delight to hear. The writing is spectacular and the game is absolutely hilarious. The dialogue is full of jokes and quips and even the background gags demand you watch all parts of the scene instead of just the character interaction. Finally, the gameplay is absolutely stellar. The world is alive with the music playing in Chai's ears and it reacts to the beat of every new song thrown to you in a whirlwind of rock. Combat follows the beat of this same music and the game never punishes you for getting the beat wrong, but instead rewards you for getting it right. There is a toggleable metronome if you aren't great at rhythm games, but after a while you start to develop a flow for the songs (which range from various tempos) and audio/visual cues to not need it so much anymore. Overall, a fantastic game and well worth every penny.

I've got no complaints. The only way it could have been improved was if The Pillows did the soundtrack. The story and characters and vibe is equal parts punk rock and Saturday morning cartoon, with silly lighthearted characters and plot that works because the game just doesn't take itself seriously. It's short, campy, endlessly energetic and likable, with tight gameplay that constantly builds on itself and never asks for a grind with music that slaps hard. Temper your expectations, this game doesn't want you to take it seriously. If you think the dialogue is cringe and stupid, tweak your mindset. The physical comedy has some genuinely laugh aloud moments, too. One scene with a certain tall red haired Scottish lady stands out. Add to that it has no microtransactions. no in-game purchases. No cringe advertising or pre orders. Hell, the game was released on the day it was announced. That's so righteous. I don't want a sequel. I just want this little star to shine bright and be remembered fondly. But it's absolutely slaying the competition, so of course we're gonna see it get ran into the ground by Bethesda. Dangit I made myself sad.

A pleasant surprise, for sure. This is what all video games should strive to be: focused, slick, and well-executed. Whoever thought to marry rhythm game timing with hack 'n' slash melee combat is a genius. Mechanically, this game is nearly perfect. Timing your moves to the beat of a song is incredibly satisfying. And while it takes some getting used to at first, once you get into it, it is the most outstanding combat system I've ever seen. The game does a fantastic job of drip-feeding you new mechanics--from basic attacks to combos to dodging and parrying to special attacks--so that it never feels stale or repetitive. However, Hi-Fi Rush does get in the way of itself a bit: In the latter half of the game, there is an over-reliance on quick-time events and mildly frustrating mini-games. Later enemies also have these annoying multi-parry mini-games that stop the flow of combat dead; they're not awful, but I could have done without them. Some of the combat encounters could also feel a little chaotic--to the point where rhythm and timing get lost in favor of simply trying not to die. Boss fights, on the other hand, are flawless--and do exactly what boss fights should do: test you on your mastery of the core mechanics learned in each stage. Yet none of this would work nearly as well as it does were it not for the audio-visual arrangement. The soundtrack and the environmental details all provide cues for the player to keep to beat--and therefore excel at the combat. There's a mix of genres to set the tone of each level and keep things interesting. But generally, if you like rock music, you are going to be well-catered for here. There was the occasional jazzy track that made it difficult to keep time, but, for the most part, the music is excellent. And the visuals are also slick: it has a comic book/anime sort of aesthetic. The world and character designs are perfect for the tone of the game, and I never tired of looking at them. The cutscenes are awesome--so vibrant and kinetic. It has a timeless quality--and without setting my graphics card on fire. All that said, the story is probably the weakest element of the game. For the most part, it is a has-been-done-before taking-down-an-evil-corporation plot. It is a little juvenile for me. The main character could also grate a little bit. He's basically an idiot that lucks his way through every situation. But by the end, he was mildly tolerable. Some people might like this but not me. However, the story did have its bright spots: it could make me chuckle from time to time. My conclusion is this: Hi-Fi Rush is an enjoyable game and a breath of fresh air in an industry that has been stagnating for some time now. I think most people will like this game; however, your mileage may vary depending on skilled you are at keeping to a beat.

Hi-Fi Rush is an example of a game that LOOKS like it should be great, so people assume it is. While the game is visually stunning, the gameplay is one-note, the voice acting is mediocre, the dialogue is awful, and the story is so cliche that I upset myself thinking they would actually take an interesting turn near the start of the third act of the story, but they failed miserably and then I remembered what game I was playing. Setting your game up to be an action rhythm game is such and interesting idea that they do NOTHING with. It literally boils down to “play on the beat”. The beat never changes. The time signature never changes. You can’t come up with your own rhythms to make combos. It’s literally “here’s a small list of moves that make combos if you press this short combination”. The second I realized you wouldn’t have any personal expression in your gameplay, I was bored. Then I continued with this travesty of a game until the ending because I figured it had to get better. It doesn’t. Every fight, the whole momentum of the game stops, and the enemies show up and posture for 2 seconds before anything happens. Then, if you defeat those enemies, a short cutscene plays in the middle of every wave and the enemies show up and posture. This happens, EVERY SINGLE TIME. And as you’re running through a stage, your companions will chime in with something or other every 10 seconds the ENTIRE GAME. “Use the generator, Chai”, “I can break that door, Chai”. Non stop. All game. And let’s not forget the AWFUL platforming. Chai jumps up and down like he’s made of lead. I haven’t felt platforming this bad since early PS1 games, and I’m not very sure it was that bad back then. Its safe to say that I hated every second of this game from about the 2 minutes mark of actual gameplay. For a game that everyone is raving about, I think it’s an absolute joke of a game with wasted potential, annoying characters, a bad story, and stale gameplay. Good thing this is on Game Pass, but even then it’s got a 5% completion rating. Makes me think that people don’t really care for it as much as they claim. And that would make sense. It’s bad.

Wonderful game that has fantastic gameplay, awesome combat, killer soundtrack, Slick controls and a fun factor that is very high. Feel the vibe, kick some butt and enjoy this wonderful surprise of a game. It is one of the few games that I have ever heard of that made possible to match its game play with all of its music and sound effects.Everything goes with the beat, making everything in its world feel so much more alive.But it is even better, I would not believe that a game that plays a hack 'n slash that makes me remember of the Devil May Cry series would work so well with a completely rhythmic mechanic. But it does!And one of the reasons is because of something so simple:while many other games try to play with rhythmic games using negative reinforcement (most cases heavily penalizes for failure), Hi-Fi Rush works primarily with positive reinforcement (most cases rewards you for playing with the beat).As with anything else, one or two minor problem in an area or another, but would really be nitpicking on my part.

Hitting all the right buttons at the right time in the right rhythm, Hi-FI Rush is a love letter to japanese rhythm games, pop-punk of the 00's, beat 'em ups' and platformers. Like a breath of fresh air in the heavy dusty air of flopped triple-A on top of flopped triple-A, it drops in at a very humble 30 euros like that cool careless friend of yours that's always late but makes all conversations feel velvet smooth effortlessly. Most of all it feels minty fresh to play a game that doesn't take itself too seriously and has fun with its characters instead of trying to engage in deep thematics and theatrics to strike a cord. The storyline does not reinvent the wheel, but you can feel that the developers had a blast incorporating the characters into the gameplay and did so very meticulously. Favorite part: Hearing The Progidy's iconic "Invaders Must Die" rev up as you smash into the evil corporate tower of Vandelay and start beating the **** out of hordes of cafeteria robots to the beat. A feeling i can only describe as maniacal smiling and intense goosebumps. Don't sleep on the fun. Plug in your stereo, kick up your feet and grip your joy pad tightly as this game absorbs you into the video game equivalent of mid-00's Avril Lavigne and No doubt.

Apenas uma experiência divertida e muito bem feita. 11/10

Hi-Fi Rush é um jogo maravilhoso que saiu da equipe do pai do survival horror, o que deixa muita gente confusa, afinal, um hack n' slash rítmico vindo da equipe do pai do survival horror? Pois é. Hi-Fi Rush é um jogo para mostrar que a Tango GameWorks não depende apenas de The Evil Within ou Ghostwire, ela pode desenvolver jogos de diferentes gêneros, com diferentes estilos gráficos, e ainda assim ele será incrível. A direção artística do jogo é fenomenal, o estilo cartunesco com cenários em 3D e cell shadding funcionam como um finíssimo vinho, e vão permitir ao jogo que envelheça muito bem. A mecânica de gameplay é extremamente divertida e fluida, se comportando de forma semelhante a outros hack n slash, mas inovando em como manter pontuações, afinal, estamos falando de um jogo rítmico. Para um bom jogo rítmico funcionar, precisamos de uma excelente trilha sonora, e é exatamente o que temos em Hi-Fi Rush, o sample base é maravilhoso, e conforme vamos acertando os golpes a intensidade da trilha vai aumentando, até mesmo quando quebramos caixotes em busca de peças escutamos a plateia gritando pelo nosso protagonista "CHAI, CHAI, CHAI!". Este jogo veio para surpreender todos os jogadores e mostrar que jogos não precisam ter medo de serem apenas jogos. Realismo gráfico, histórias dramáticas, pra que? Nossa vida já é cheia de tristezas, está na hora de voltarmos a nos divertir, e se divertir com Hi-Fi Rush!

The TLDR version is that Hi Fi Rush is one of the best games to come out in a long time, especially from Microsoft, who finally has a legit series on their hand that isn't stuck in the past(Halo) or possibly stuck in development Hell(Star field). The game can truly be one of their premier series, and Chai(The MC) could become a mascot of sorts for Microsoft alongside Chief, giving them a sort of counter to Sony who has Kratos and Ellie, or Nintendo who has Mario and Link. As for the inner workings of the game... Pros:-Fantastic soundtrack: Weather you're using the licensed music or turned on the option for only original songs, the game is a bop all the way through and will have you tapping your foot the entire time. -Smooth gameplay: Locked at a consistent frame rate without any issues. I played this on both my PC(Intel Core 9, Nividia 3080) and Xbox Series X and both ran fantastically, to the point where I was running at 4K, 144FPS without a single issue. For those with less powerful PC's, the game has the option to cap the frame rate as low as 24FPS, so unless you're build is pre-2013, you should have no issues. -Smooth combat: The combat is easy to learn but hard to master. The game has a very nice progression system where you start off with very basic combos, yet you quickly gain the ability to upgrade as soon as you beat the first stage. You can also cancel out of combos without issue, meaning you don't have to worry about getting locked in a combo right when you're about to get hit. The game also rewards you for timing your hits to the beat of the music, as it will deal more damage and give more bolts(In game currency.) For those who worry they don't have any rhythm, not only does the game not punish you for not being on beat, but you also have the option to bring up a meter that will show you when the beat of the song hits, making it very new comer friendly. -Story and Characters: In all honesty, the story is rather simple, as you and a ragtag group of friends have to take down the evil corporation, but it does have some subtle twists I enjoy. For one, hints throughout the game show that the company wasn't always evil and was once used for good before the new ownership took over, which is a nice twist as it shows it's not corporations themselves that are evil, but rather the power hungry investors who get in charge. I also really enjoy the rag tag group of friends you get, who I won't be spoiling, but they all work wonderfully together and by the end, they truly feel like a team who have been through Hell and back together. -No Micro transactions: Pretty simple, the game is 30 dollars and you don't pay a cent more unless you get the deluxe pack which gives you a few extra costumes to wear. Other than that, you can't buy anything in the game. You want more ingame currency? Go kill robots. Want that super cool technique? You gotta buy it with ingame currency. You want this graffiti to hang up in the hideout? Go find it in one of the levels first. This is what gaming used to be about, using your own skills and knowledge of the game to aquire collectibles instead of buying them with real money. -You can pet the cat: I mean...Who doesn't want to pet the cat? Negatives -Platforming: Easily the worst part of the game is the platforming, though this is somewhat mitigated by a midair slide that can be useful for aiming against the wall so you don't overshoot. Still, the controls don't differ between combat and platforming, and while the jumping is super slick for flying around and killing enemies...Not so much when you need to make precise jumps, other than risking a fall(Though a fall thankfully only takes a little bit of health and doesn't cause a game over.) A little forced romance: This is a nitpick, but near the end of the game, two characters are either implied to have feelings for each other, or atleast one has a crush on the other. This is fine, yet it's never brought up at all in the game, and feels a bit forced at the end. For a game that has a amazing story and characters, it feels a bit out of left field. Overall: Overall, Hi Fi rush is one of the best games Bethesda has made in quite a long time, and shows that AA gaming can still thrive in this market. With a campaign close to 11 hours long, with quite a bit of post game content, the game is not only worth 30 dollars, but it's almost highway robbery. Weather you like rhythm games or not, this is a game everyone has to try out atleast once.

this game rocks Hi-Fi RUSH's gameplay, visual design, and music all weave together to create an experience unlike any other hack 'n slash or beat 'em up I've played. The rhythm-based combat is super duper interesting. While I wish they could've done something more with that - like being able to attack on off-beats or utilizing different time signatures - it's still an exhilarating experience that I adore. The visuals remind me of comic books, and the switches between 3D and 2D feel unexpected but not jarring. The cutscenes are excellent, the dialogue is funny, and the characters are booming with personality. Chai could use a bit more work, though. He's just "I wanna be a rockstar baby!!" and I feel like if he had a bit more personality, it could be better received by the public. But that's my two cents. Overall, it's a great experience if you want to run through it with story mode in mind, although replayability is lacking. That's not an issue, though, if you plan on just enjoying it from start to finish.
